snippet: Compared with other routes for refugees crossing the Mediterranean, the journey from Bodrum to Kos is remarkably organized and unfettered.
abstract: Greek island Kos is grappling with how to humanely accommodate overwhelming flood of migrants and refugees making Mediterranean crossing from Turkish coastal town of Bodrum; Greece says sheer magnitude of arrivals, reportedly 134,988 in 2015 alone, is more than crisis-ridden country can bear and while some blame Turkey for lax control, officials there say wave of human smuggling is equally difficult to curb from their side; most migrants are escaping violence in Afghanistan, Iraq and Syria.

byline.original: By CEYLAN YEGINSU and ANEMONA HARTOCOLLIS
byline.contributor: Ceylan Yeginsu reported from Bodrum, Turkey, and Anemona Hartocollis from Kos, Greece.

lead_paragraph: Compared with other routes for refugees crossing the Mediterranean, the journey from Bodrum to Kos is remarkably organized and unfettered.

headline.main: Amid Perilous Mediterranean Crossings, Migrants Find a Relatively Easy Path to Greece
headline.print_headline: For Migrants, a Relatively Easy Path to Greece

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
